canonical_explanation.text: Friction is a force that opposes the relative motion between two surfaces in contact. It is caused by the irregularities (roughness) on the surfaces that interlock with each other. Friction depends on the nature of the surfaces and the force pressing them together. There are three types of friction: static friction (opposes the tendency to move), sliding friction (opposes sliding motion), and rolling friction (opposes rolling motion). Static friction is the greatest, followed by sliding friction, and rolling friction is the least. Friction has both advantages (walking, writing, braking) and disadvantages (wear, heat, energy loss). Friction can be increased by making surfaces rough and reduced by using lubricants, ball bearings, polishing, or streamlining.
rules: Friction opposes the relative motion between two surfaces in contact.
Friction is caused by irregularities (interlocking) of surfaces.
Friction depends on the nature of surfaces and the weight (normal force) pressing them together.
Static friction > Sliding friction > Rolling friction.
Static friction: opposes the tendency of an object to start moving.
Sliding friction: opposes the sliding motion of an object.
Rolling friction: opposes the rolling motion of an object.
Advantages: walking, writing, braking, holding objects.
Disadvantages: wear and tear, heat generation, energy loss.
Friction can be reduced by lubricants, ball bearings, polishing, or streamlined shapes.

questions.question_text: Friction is a force that:

options.text: Opposes the relative motion between two surfaces

questions.explanation_correct: Friction is a force that opposes the relative motion between two surfaces in contact. It acts whenever two surfaces are in contact and there is a tendency for motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Friction does not always help motion (A); it can oppose it. Friction acts on both smooth and rough surfaces (C, D), though rough surfaces produce more friction. The correct definition is that friction opposes relative motion (B).

questions.question_text: Friction is caused by:

options.text: Irregularities on the surfaces in contact

questions.explanation_correct: Friction is caused by the irregularities (tiny bumps and grooves) on surfaces that interlock with each other when two surfaces come in contact, opposing relative motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gravity (A) presses surfaces together but is not the direct cause of friction. Colour (B) and temperature (D) do not cause friction. Irregularities on surfaces (C) interlocking with each other is the cause of friction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following factors affects friction?

options.text: Nature of the surfaces in contact

questions.explanation_correct: Friction depends on the nature of the surfaces in contact — rough surfaces produce more friction than smooth surfaces. The other factor is the force pressing the surfaces together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Colour (A), temperature (C), and size (D) do not directly affect friction. Friction depends on the nature (roughness) of surfaces (B) and the force pressing them together.

questions.question_text: Friction between two surfaces increases when:

options.text: The force pressing the surfaces together is increased

questions.explanation_correct: Friction increases when the force pressing the surfaces together increases. A heavier object presses harder on the surface, causing the irregularities to interlock more tightly, increasing friction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Making surfaces smoother (A), applying lubricant (B), and polishing (D) all reduce friction. Increasing the pressing force (C) increases the interlocking of surface irregularities, thereby increasing friction.

questions.question_text: Which type of friction is the greatest?
questions.explanation_correct: Static friction is the greatest among the three types. It takes more force to start moving an object than to keep it moving. The order is: Static friction > Sliding friction > Rolling friction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rolling friction (A) is the least of all. Sliding friction (B) is less than static. Fluid friction (D) varies. Static friction (C) is the greatest because it resists the initiation of motion.

questions.question_text: The friction experienced by an object rolling on a surface is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Rolling friction is the friction experienced when an object rolls over a surface. It is much less than sliding friction, which is why wheels and ball bearings are used to reduce friction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Static friction (A) prevents an object from starting to move. Sliding friction (B) acts when an object slides. Fluid friction (D) acts in fluids. Rolling friction (C) is the correct term for friction during rolling.

questions.question_text: Why is it easier to move a heavy box by placing it on rollers than by sliding it?

options.text: Rollers reduce the weight of the box
Rolling friction is much less than sliding friction
Rollers increase the area of contact

questions.explanation_correct: Rollers convert sliding friction into rolling friction. Since rolling friction is much less than sliding friction, it becomes easier to move the heavy box on rollers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rollers do not reduce the weight (A). They don't necessarily increase the area (C). Rollers do not eliminate friction completely (D) — they reduce it by converting sliding friction to rolling friction (B), which is much smaller.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an advantage of friction?

options.text: Wear and tear of soles of shoes
Being able to walk on the ground

questions.explanation_correct: Walking on the ground is possible because of friction between our shoes and the ground. Without friction, our feet would slip and we could not walk. This is an important advantage of friction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wear and tear (A), heat in machines (B), and difficulty moving heavy objects (D) are all disadvantages of friction. Being able to walk (C) is an advantage — friction between our feet and the ground allows us to push off and move forward.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a disadvantage of friction?

options.text: Writing with a pencil on paper
Wear and tear of machine parts
Holding a glass without it slipping

questions.explanation_correct: Wear and tear of machine parts is a disadvantage of friction. When moving parts rub against each other, friction gradually wears them away, reducing their efficiency and lifespan.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Writing (A), braking (B), and holding a glass (D) are all advantages of friction. Wear and tear (C) is a disadvantage because friction gradually damages surfaces that rub against each other.

questions.question_text: Which of the following methods reduces friction?

options.text: Increasing the weight of the object

questions.explanation_correct: Applying lubricants (like oil or grease) reduces friction by filling the irregularities between surfaces and creating a thin layer that prevents direct contact between the surfaces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Making surfaces rougher (A) and adding sand (B) increase friction. Increasing weight (D) increases the force pressing surfaces together, increasing friction. Only applying lubricants (C) reduces friction.

questions.question_text: Friction always opposes motion, so it is always undesirable.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. While friction does oppose motion, it is not always undesirable. Friction is essential for walking, writing, braking vehicles, and holding objects. Without friction, many daily activities would be impossible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Friction is not always undesirable. It is necessary for walking, writing, braking, and many other everyday activities. Its disadvantages include wear and tear, but friction is both helpful and harmful.

questions.question_text: Rolling friction is always greater than sliding friction.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Rolling friction is always less than sliding friction. The order is: Static friction > Sliding friction > Rolling friction. This is why wheels and ball bearings are used to reduce friction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rolling friction is less than sliding friction, not greater. This is the reason why it is easier to roll a heavy barrel than to slide it along the ground.

questions.question_text: Sprinkling powder on a carrom board reduces friction between the striker and the board.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Powder on a carrom board acts as a lubricant that fills the irregularities on the surface and reduces friction, allowing the striker and coins to glide smoothly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The fine powder reduces friction by filling surface irregularities and creating a smoother surface for the striker and coins to move on.

questions.question_text: Friction is caused by the ___ on the surfaces in contact.
questions.explanation_correct: Friction is caused by the irregularities (tiny bumps and grooves) on surfaces. These irregularities interlock when surfaces are in contact, resisting relative motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'irregularities'. Even surfaces that appear smooth have tiny irregularities at the microscopic level, and these cause friction when surfaces come in contact.

questions.question_text: The friction that opposes the tendency of an object to start moving is called ___ friction.
questions.explanation_correct: Static friction opposes the tendency of a stationary object to begin moving. It is the strongest type of friction and must be overcome to start moving an object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'static'. Static friction acts on objects that are not yet moving but have a tendency to move due to an applied force.

questions.question_text: Substances like oil and grease applied between moving parts to reduce friction are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Lubricants are substances applied between moving surfaces to reduce friction. They fill the irregularities and create a smooth layer, reducing direct contact between the surfaces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'lubricants'. Oil, grease, and other lubricants reduce friction by filling surface irregularities and preventing direct surface-to-surface contact.

questions.question_text: A person slips on a wet floor because:

options.text: Water acts as a lubricant and reduces friction

questions.explanation_correct: Water on the floor acts as a lubricant between the shoe and the floor surface. It fills the irregularities, reduces friction, and makes the surface slippery, causing the person to slip.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The floor does not become heavier (A), gravity does not increase (C), and the person's weight stays the same (D). Water acts as a lubricant (B), reducing friction between the shoe and the floor.

questions.question_text: Why do tyres of vehicles have grooves (treads) on their surface?

options.text: To reduce friction with the road
To increase friction for better grip on the road

questions.explanation_correct: Treads on tyres increase friction between the tyre and the road surface. This provides better grip, especially on wet or uneven roads, ensuring safer driving and effective braking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Treads are not for appearance (A). They do not reduce friction (B) or make tyres lighter (D). Treads increase friction (C), providing better grip and control on the road.

questions.question_text: Ball bearings are used in machines to:

options.text: Convert sliding friction into rolling friction
Increase the weight of the machine

questions.explanation_correct: Ball bearings convert sliding friction into rolling friction. Since rolling friction is much less than sliding friction, ball bearings significantly reduce friction in machines, making them run more smoothly and efficiently.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ball bearings do not increase sliding friction (A), add weight (C), or generate heat (D). They reduce friction by converting sliding into rolling friction (B), which is much smaller.

questions.question_text: When you rub your palms together quickly, they feel warm because:

options.text: Friction between the palms converts kinetic energy into heat
The air around your hands heats up
Your blood circulation increases in the palms

questions.explanation_correct: When you rub your palms together, friction between the two surfaces converts kinetic energy (energy of motion) into heat energy. This is why your palms feel warm after rubbing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The primary reason is friction converting kinetic energy into heat (B). While blood circulation may increase slightly (D), the immediate warmth is due to friction generating heat, not overall body temperature increase (A) or air heating (C).

questions.question_text: Why is it difficult to walk on a smooth, icy surface?

options.text: There is very little friction between shoes and ice

questions.explanation_correct: Walking on ice is difficult because the friction between shoes and the icy surface is very low. Ice is smooth, so there are fewer irregularities to interlock with the shoe surface, making it very slippery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The temperature (A), weight of ice (C), and gravity (D) are not the reasons. The low friction (B) between shoes and the smooth icy surface makes it difficult to walk.

questions.question_text: Streamlined shapes are used in vehicles and aeroplanes to:
questions.explanation_correct: Streamlined shapes reduce fluid friction (air resistance or drag). The smooth, pointed shape allows air to flow smoothly around the vehicle, reducing the opposing force and allowing higher speeds with less energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Streamlining is not for appearance (A), increasing road friction (C), or adding weight (D). It reduces fluid friction (B) — the resistance offered by air or water to the motion of the vehicle.

questions.question_text: It is harder to push a heavy almirah (cupboard) than a light chair because:

options.text: The almirah has a smoother surface
The heavier almirah has greater friction with the floor
The almirah is made of a different material

questions.explanation_correct: A heavier object presses harder on the surface, increasing the interlocking of irregularities and thus the friction. The heavy almirah has greater friction with the floor compared to a light chair.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Surface smoothness (A) and material (D) may play a role, but the primary reason is the greater weight. The chair does not have more friction (C). The heavier almirah generates more friction (B) due to the greater pressing force.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following in decreasing order of friction: static friction, rolling friction, sliding friction.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct decreasing order of friction is: Static friction > Sliding friction > Rolling friction. It takes the most force to start an object moving (static), less to keep it sliding, and the least to keep it rolling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is Static > Sliding > Rolling (C). Options A, B, and D have the wrong order. Static friction is always the greatest, and rolling friction is always the least.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about friction is correct?

options.text: Friction only acts on moving objects
Friction produces heat, which is always useful

questions.explanation_correct: Friction is called a 'necessary evil' because it has both advantages and disadvantages. It is necessary for activities like walking and writing, but it also causes wear and tear and wastes energy as heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Friction also acts on stationary objects as static friction (A). The heat produced is not always useful (B) — it can damage machines. Friction cannot be completely eliminated (D). Calling friction a 'necessary evil' (C) correctly captures its dual nature.

questions.question_text: A sports shoe has spikes on its sole. The purpose of these spikes is to:

options.text: Increase friction for a better grip on the ground
Reduce friction so the player can run faster

questions.explanation_correct: Spikes on sports shoes increase friction between the shoe and the ground. This provides a better grip, preventing slipping, especially on grass or soft surfaces, allowing athletes to run, turn, and stop safely.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spikes do not make shoes lighter (A), reduce friction (C), or make them waterproof (D). Spikes increase friction (B) by digging into the ground, providing better traction and grip for athletes.

questions.question_text: When a matchstick is struck against the rough side of a matchbox, it lights up because:

options.text: Friction produces enough heat to ignite the matchstick
The rough surface provides air to the matchstick

questions.explanation_correct: Friction between the matchstick head and the rough surface generates heat. This heat is sufficient to reach the ignition temperature of the chemicals on the matchstick head, causing it to light up.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While the matchbox does have chemicals (A), the key role is played by friction generating heat (B). The matchstick doesn't absorb light (C). Air supply (D) is not the primary reason. Friction produces the heat needed for ignition.

questions.question_text: A block placed on a table does not move even when a small force is applied. This is because:

options.text: Static friction is greater than the applied force
There is no friction between the block and the table

questions.explanation_correct: The block does not move because the static friction between the block and the table is greater than or equal to the applied force. As long as the applied force does not exceed the maximum static friction, the block will not move.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The block has weight (A). There is friction between the block and table (C). The applied force does not increase friction (D). The block stays still because static friction balances the applied force (B).

questions.question_text: In which of the following cases is friction deliberately increased?

options.text: Using ball bearings in a motor

questions.explanation_correct: When brakes are applied, brake pads press against the wheel or disc, increasing friction. This friction converts the kinetic energy of the vehicle into heat, slowing it down and eventually stopping it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oiling (A), ball bearings (B), and polishing (D) all reduce friction. Applying brakes (C) deliberately increases friction to slow down and stop the vehicle.

questions.question_text: Why do gymnasts apply chalk powder on their hands?

options.text: To absorb sweat and increase friction for a better grip
To reduce friction and swing faster

questions.explanation_correct: Gymnasts apply chalk powder to absorb sweat from their hands. Sweat acts as a lubricant and reduces friction. By absorbing sweat, the chalk increases friction, providing a better grip on apparatus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chalk does not make hands smooth (A), reduce friction (C), or cool hands (D). It absorbs sweat (which reduces friction) and thus increases friction (B) for a better grip.

questions.question_text: Friction does not depend on the weight of the object.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Friction depends on the weight (or more precisely, the normal force) pressing the surfaces together. A heavier object presses harder and experiences greater friction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Friction depends on two main factors: the nature of surfaces and the force pressing them together (related to weight). Heavier objects experience more friction.

questions.question_text: Streamlined bodies experience less fluid friction than flat-fronted bodies.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Streamlined shapes allow fluids (air or water) to flow smoothly around them, reducing the fluid friction (drag). This is why fish, birds, and high-speed vehicles have streamlined bodies.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Streamlined bodies indeed experience less fluid friction. Their smooth, tapered shape allows air or water to flow with minimal resistance, unlike flat surfaces that push against the fluid.

questions.question_text: Without friction, it would be impossible to write with a pencil on paper.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. When we write, friction between the pencil tip and the paper causes graphite particles to rub off and stick to the paper. Without friction, the pencil would simply slide over the paper without leaving any marks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Writing requires friction between the pencil and paper. Friction causes graphite to transfer from the pencil to the paper surface.

questions.question_text: The correct order of friction from greatest to least is: static friction > ___ friction > rolling friction.
questions.explanation_correct: The order is Static > Sliding > Rolling friction. Sliding friction is greater than rolling but less than static friction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'sliding'. The complete order is: Static friction > Sliding friction > Rolling friction.

questions.question_text: The friction exerted by air or water on objects moving through them is called ___ friction.
questions.explanation_correct: Fluid friction (or drag) is the friction exerted by fluids (liquids and gases, including air and water) on objects moving through them. It can be reduced by using streamlined shapes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fluid'. Fluid friction acts when objects move through liquids or gases. It is also called drag.

questions.question_text: A book placed on a tilted surface starts sliding down when the tilt angle is increased. This happens because:

options.text: The component of gravity along the surface exceeds static friction
The surface becomes smoother when tilted

questions.explanation_correct: As the tilt increases, the component of the book's weight along the surface increases. When this component exceeds the maximum static friction, the book starts sliding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The book's weight doesn't change (A). Friction doesn't disappear (C). The surface doesn't become smoother (D). The book slides because the gravitational force along the slope exceeds the static friction (B).

questions.question_text: Why are the soles of shoes made with rough, textured surfaces?

options.text: To make the shoes cheaper to produce
To increase friction and prevent slipping
To reduce friction and make walking easier

questions.explanation_correct: Rough, textured soles increase friction between the shoe and the ground. This greater friction prevents the foot from slipping, especially on smooth or wet surfaces, ensuring safe walking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The rough texture is not about cost (A), reducing friction (C), or weight (D). It increases friction (B) between the sole and the ground to provide a better grip and prevent slipping.

questions.question_text: Two identical blocks are placed on a surface. Block A has a mass of 2 kg and Block B has a mass of 5 kg. Which block experiences more friction when pushed?
questions.explanation_correct: Block B (5 kg) experiences more friction because it is heavier. Greater weight means a greater force pressing the surfaces together, which increases the interlocking of irregularities and therefore the friction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since both blocks have the same surface, the difference in friction is due to weight. Block A (A) is lighter and has less friction. They do not have equal friction (C). It can be determined (D). Block B (B) has more friction due to its greater weight.

questions.question_text: In machines, friction is considered a disadvantage primarily because it:

options.text: Causes wear and tear of parts and wastes energy as heat
Changes the colour of machine parts

questions.explanation_correct: In machines, friction causes wear and tear of moving parts, reducing their lifespan. It also converts useful kinetic energy into heat, reducing the efficiency of the machine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Friction doesn't make machines heavier (A) or change colours (D). While it may contribute to noise (C), the primary disadvantages are wear and tear and energy loss as heat (B).

questions.question_text: Which body shape experiences the least fluid friction (drag)?
questions.explanation_correct: A streamlined (fish-like) shape experiences the least fluid friction because it allows the fluid (air or water) to flow smoothly around it with minimal resistance. This is why fish, birds, and high-speed vehicles have streamlined shapes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Flat (A) and cubic (D) shapes create maximum drag. A sphere (B) has moderate drag. The streamlined shape (C) offers the least resistance to fluid flow.

questions.question_text: It is easier to pull a suitcase with wheels than to drag it because:

options.text: Wheels convert sliding friction to rolling friction, which is much less
Wheels increase the area of contact

questions.explanation_correct: Wheels convert sliding friction into rolling friction. Since rolling friction is much less than sliding friction, a suitcase with wheels is much easier to move than dragging it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wheels don't make the suitcase lighter (A), eliminate friction entirely (C), or increase contact area (D). They convert sliding to rolling friction (B), which is significantly less.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true about friction?

options.text: Friction acts in the direction of motion
Friction acts opposite to the direction of motion or tendency of motion
Friction acts perpendicular to the surface
Friction acts only when objects are stationary

questions.explanation_correct: Friction always acts in the direction opposite to the motion or the tendency of motion of an object. This opposing nature is what defines friction as a resistive force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Friction does not act in the direction of motion (A) or perpendicular to the surface (C) — that is the normal force. Friction acts on both moving and stationary objects (D). It acts opposite to the direction of motion (B).

questions.question_text: A car comes to a stop after the brakes are applied. The energy of the car's motion is converted into:
questions.explanation_correct: When brakes are applied, friction between the brake pads and the wheel converts the kinetic energy (energy of motion) of the car into heat energy. This is why brake discs become hot after heavy braking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While a small amount of energy may be converted to sound (B), the vast majority is converted to heat energy (C) due to friction between the brake pads and wheel. It is not converted to light (A) or chemical energy (D).

questions.question_text: Friction is called a ___ evil because it is both useful and harmful.
questions.explanation_correct: Friction is called a 'necessary evil' because we cannot do without it (walking, writing, braking all need friction) but it also has harmful effects (wear, heat, energy loss).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'necessary'. Friction is described as a necessary evil because it is essential for many activities but also causes problems like wear and tear.

questions.question_text: Friction depends on the nature of the surfaces and the ___ pressing them together.
questions.explanation_correct: The two main factors that affect friction are the nature (roughness) of the surfaces in contact and the force pressing them together. Greater pressing force leads to more friction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'force'. Friction increases when the force pressing the surfaces together increases, because the surface irregularities interlock more tightly.

questions.question_text: Why is it easier to start a car on a rough road than on an icy road?

options.text: The engine works better on rough roads
Rough roads provide more friction for the tyres to grip

questions.explanation_correct: A rough road provides more friction between the tyres and the surface. This friction allows the tyres to grip the road and push the car forward. On icy roads, friction is very low, causing the tyres to spin without gripping.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Engine performance is not affected by road type (A). Ice doesn't change the car's weight (C). Gravity is the same everywhere (D). Rough roads provide better grip through greater friction (B).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a method to reduce friction?
questions.explanation_correct: Making surfaces rough increases friction, not reduces it. Lubricants, ball bearings, and polishing are all methods to reduce friction between surfaces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lubricants (A), ball bearings (B), and polishing (D) all reduce friction. Making surfaces rough (C) increases friction and is therefore not a method to reduce it.

questions.question_text: Two blocks of same material but different weights are placed on the same surface. The friction acting on them will be:
questions.explanation_correct: The heavier block presses harder on the surface, causing greater interlocking of surface irregularities. This results in more friction acting on the heavier block compared to the lighter one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Friction is not the same (A) because the weights differ. The lighter block has less friction (B is wrong). Friction is not zero (D). The heavier block experiences more friction (C) due to the greater pressing force.

questions.question_text: Friction can never produce heat.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Friction always produces heat when surfaces rub against each other. Rubbing your palms together, a matchstick lighting up, and brake discs getting hot are all examples of friction producing heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Friction converts kinetic energy into heat energy. Examples include rubbing hands together, striking a matchstick, and braking in vehicles.

questions.question_text: Fish have a streamlined body shape because:

options.text: It helps them to breathe underwater
It minimises water resistance (fluid friction) while swimming
It helps them to catch prey

questions.explanation_correct: Fish have a streamlined body shape to minimise fluid friction (water resistance). The smooth, tapering shape allows water to flow around them easily, enabling efficient and fast movement through water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Breathing (A), catching prey (C), and predator protection (D) are not the primary reasons for streamlined shape. The streamlined body minimises water resistance (B), allowing fish to swim efficiently.
